abstract.text: A view that blends virtual 3D content from SceneKit into your augmented reality experience.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: class provides the easiest way to create augmented reality experiences that blend virtual 3D content with a device camera view of the real world. When you run the view’s provided
The view automatically renders the live video feed from the device camera as the scene background.
The world coordinate system of the view’s SceneKit scene directly responds to the AR world coordinate system established by the session configuration.
The view automatically moves its SceneKit camera to match the real-world movement of the device.

ARKit automatically matches SceneKit’s coordinate space to the real world, so after you place your app’s virtual content, it maintains the illusion of resting in the real-world as the user moves the device. See
You don’t necessarily need to use the
class to track positions of objects you add to the scene, but by implementing
methods, you can add SceneKit content to any anchors that are automatically detected by ARKit.
Because ARKit requires Metal, use only Metal features of SceneKit. For example:
instances with Metal Shading Language code.
, the framework reverts the value to

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
An object that specifies the position and orientation of an item in the physical environment.
A view that displays standardized onboarding instructions to direct users toward a specific goal.
Options for drawing overlay content to aid debugging of AR tracking in a SceneKit view.
A view that blends virtual 3D content from SceneKit into your augmented reality experience.
Returns the AR anchor associated with the specified SceneKit node, if any.
A Boolean value that specifies whether ARKit creates and updates SceneKit lights in the view’s scene.
An object you provide to mediate synchronization of the view’s AR scene information with SceneKit content.
Searches for real-world objects or AR anchors in the captured camera image corresponding to a point in the SceneKit view.
Returns the SceneKit node associated with the specified AR anchor, if any.
Creates a raycast query that originates from a point on the view, aligned with the center of the camera’s field of view.
A flag that determines whether SceneKit applies image noise characteristics to your app’s virtual content.
Determines whether the view renders motion blur.
The SceneKit scene to be displayed in the view.
The AR session that manages motion tracking and camera image processing for the view’s contents.
Returns the projection of a point from 2D view onto a plane in the 3D world space detected by ARKit.
Returns the projection of a point from 2D view onto a plane in the 3D world space detected by ARKit.
Methods you can implement to mediate the automatic synchronization of SceneKit content with an AR session.
A view that blends virtual 2D content from SpriteKit into the 3D space of an augmented reality experience.
The object that manages the major tasks associated with every AR experience, such as motion tracking, camera passthrough, and image analysis.
An object that provides a session.
Use SceneKit to add realistic three-dimensional objects to your AR experience.
A view that enables you to display an AR experience with RealityKit.
A complete Metal or OpenGL shader program that replaces SceneKit’s rendering of a geometry or material.
Use the Metal framework for SceneKit rendering.
Use the OpenGL ES 2.0 API for SceneKit rendering in iOS.
The rendering API to use for rendering the view (for example, Metal or OpenGL).
A view for displaying 3D SceneKit content.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.

Methods and properties common to the [`SCNView`](doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNView), [`SCNLayer`](doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNLayer), and [`SCNRenderer`](doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNRenderer) classes.
The common interface for SceneKit objects that support multipass rendering using [`SCNTechnique`](doc://com.apple.scenekit/documentation/SceneKit/SCNTechnique) objects.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
